William Garvey

By JAY S. GOODGOLD
Only 35 intersession courses
are to be offered in January,
continuing the downward trend
in number of offerings for the
second year in a row, amid the
possibility that the three-week
program may be cancelled
entirely due to the energy crisis.

Owen, cancellation could take
place if adequate oil supplies are
denied to Hopkins in the next
few months.
"If there's a real crisis of
substantial proportions and the
oil companies decide not to send
us enough fuel then we might
have to close the school in
January," Owen said.

OOPS! AND OTHER NOTES...
Due to a typographical error, one
paragraph of the story "AC considering
plans for Anthropology Dept." in
Friday's News-Letter was printed

Leadership, a six credit Political Science

The University Health Service (Brown
Infirmary) will be closed from 5 p.m.
Wednesday November 21, 1973 until
8:30 a.m. on Monday, November 26. The
closing of the service for the entire
Thanksgiving Holiday also represents a
close in the on-call system which serves
people with medical problems after 5
p.m. Therefore, if you will be on campus
during the 4 day holiday, students are
encouraged to go to Union Memorial
Hospital Emergency Room for treatment
of only- emergency conditions. The JHU
Student Health Insurance will only cover
treatment of emergencies (i.e. lacerations,
fractures, hospital admission for medical
illness). If there are any questions or
problems concerning this policy, please
come to the infirmary before Wednesday,
November 21. After this date call the
JHU switchboard operator.

Harriers close season with
5th place in M-D title race
By JOHN TETZLAFF
The Hopkins cross country team
finished its 1973 campaign by taking fifth
place in the Mason-Dixon Conference
Championships Saturday afternoon at
Cockeysville, Md. Twelve teams
competed in the meet on the 5.0 mile
UMBC course, and the fine Blue Jay
performance was strong enough to defeat
local rival Towson State for the first time
in recent memory.
Catholic University won the meet as
expected, narrowly edging out Mount St.
Mary's, 55-63. Two Virginia schools,
Bridgewater and Roanoke, placed third
and fourth with scores of 81 and 92
respectively, to outplace the Hopkins
tally of 169.
Dynamic Duo
The Blue Jay dynamic duo of Jeff
Greve and Jim Kennedy took 16th and
17th places in times bordering 26:20 as
each sliced a minute off his time from
a mid-season meet on the same course.
Both times bettered the old course record

which the race winner from Roanoke
demolished.
Juniors John Tetzlaff and Jon Higdon
improved their previous times
significantly in taking 36th and 44th in
the race. Randy Safier rounded out the
scoring quintet, taking 56th place in the
race and giving Hopkins a 2:56 spread.
Bill Schickler added depth when he
finished within thirty minutes, cutting
1:14 off his previous UMBC time.
Coach Don Masken was pleased with
the meet and the whole season. His Blue
Jays consistently showed improvement as
the season progressed and the future
looks even stronger with the top six
runners all returning next fall.
Thus the harriers concluded their first
winning season in recent memory with
solid finishes in the Middle Atlantic
Conference, the Galludet Invitational.
and the Mason-Dixon meet. Hopefully.
when September rolls around the Blue
Jays can continue from the high point
they end on.
